title: Bob Hamelin
text:
Robert James Hamelin (; born November 29, 1967) is a former <a href="first%20baseman">first baseman</a> and <a href="designated%20hitter">designated hitter</a> in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>. From 1993 through 1998, Hamelin played for the <a href="Kansas%20City%20Royals">Kansas City Royals</a> (1993–96), <a href="Detroit%20Tigers">Detroit Tigers</a> (1997) and <a href="Milwaukee%20Brewers">Milwaukee Brewers</a> (1998). He batted and threw left-handed.
In a six-season career, Hamelin posted a .246 <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a> with 67 <a href="home%20run">home run</a>s and 209 <a href="run%20batted%20in">RBIs</a> in 497 <a href="games%20played">games played</a>. In 1994, at the age of 26, he was the <a href="American%20League">American League</a> <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20Rookie%20of%20the%20Year%20Award">Rookie of the Year</a>. But his stint as a professional player was marred by leg injuries, both in the minors and majors. He also suffered from an eye problem.
Playing career.
High school and college.
After a long and illustrious career in the Randolph Little League, Hamelin's family moved from their home in <a href="Randolph%2C%20New%20Jersey">Randolph, New Jersey</a> to <a href="Irvine%2C%20California">Irvine, California</a>, when he was 12 years old. Hamelin attended <a href="Irvine%20High%20School%20%28Irvine%2C%20California%29">Irvine High School</a> where he excelled in both <a href="high%20school%20football">football</a> and <a href="baseball">baseball</a> and was named the School's Athlete of the Year as a senior. The <a href="University%20of%20Notre%20Dame">University of Notre Dame</a> recruited him to play football, however Hamelin had already decided to pursue a career in baseball. Hamelin enrolled in <a href="Santa%20Ana%20College">Santa Ana College</a> after graduating from high school and played on the school's baseball team. Soon thereafter the young baseball prospect transferred to <a href="UCLA">UCLA</a>, where he continued to play baseball for his new school. In 1987, he played <a href="collegiate%20summer%20baseball">collegiate summer baseball</a> with the <a href="Harwich%20Mariners">Harwich Mariners</a> of the <a href="Cape%20Cod%20Baseball%20League">Cape Cod Baseball League</a>.
Major leagues.
Hamelin won the 1994 AL Rookie of the Year Award as a member of the <a href="Kansas%20City%20Royals">Kansas City Royals</a>, when he posted a .282 batting average and hit 24 <a href="home%20run">home run</a>s (earning him the nickname "the hammer") with 65 <a href="Run%20batted%20in">RBIs</a> during the <a href="1994%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20strike">strike-shortened season</a>.
After the major leagues.
Hamelin abruptly quit his professional baseball career while playing in the minor leagues for the <a href="Toledo%20Mud%20Hens">Toledo Mud Hens</a> (Detroit Tigers AAA Team) in 1999. After grounding out, he went back to the dugout and told manager <a href="Gene%20Roof">Gene Roof</a>, "I'm done", ending his professional baseball career as a player.
After retirement Hamelin was out of professional baseball for several years, owning a manufacturing company. He attended scouting school and returned to professional baseball as a <a href="scout%20%28sports%29">scout</a> for the <a href="Washington%20Nationals">Washington Nationals</a> and the <a href="Toronto%20Blue%20Jays">Toronto Blue Jays</a>. In 2012, he joined the Major League scouting corps of the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a>. His scouting contract was not renewed by the Boston Red Sox for the 2021 season.
Hamelin's 1996 <a href="Pinnacle%20Brands">Pinnacle Foil</a> <a href="baseball%20card">baseball card</a> is commonly referred to as the worst baseball card of all time. In 2019, Hamelin and a collection of his baseball cards were featured in the first episode of <a href="SB%20Nation">SB Nation</a>'s two part series "The Bob Emergency", narrated by <a href="Jon%20Bois">Jon Bois</a>.
